questions.text: Which of the following color labels is used to indicate highly toxic pesticides?
questions.solution:
• Highly toxic pesticides are labelled in yellow color.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition, Page no: 843 - 845

questions.text:
A child was brought to the primary health center for vaccination. The parents informed the medical officer that the child had a history of egg allergy. Which of the following vaccines can not be given to the child?
1. Yellow fever
2. Japanese encephalitis
3. Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)
4. Influenza
5. Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR)
questions.solution:
• In the given clinical scenario, yellow fever and influenza vaccines can not be given to a child who has an egg allergy.
  • Yellow fever and influenza vaccines are prepared in hen's egg tissues. Hence, they can not be given to a patient with a history of anaphylactic reactions following egg ingestion.
  • However, vaccine viruses propagated in chicken fibroblast cells like measles or MMR vaccines can be given.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 131

questions.text:
A child who was bitten by a stray dog was immediately brought to the primary health center. He had an abrasion on his left leg with minor bleeding. Which of the following measures should be taken immediately in this case to stop the contraction of rabies?
1. Washing the wound with soap and water for 15 minutes
2. Irrigating the wound with cetrimide + chlorhexidine
3. Infiltrate the wound with rabies immunoglobulin
4. Giving the cell culture-derived rabies vaccine
5. Suturing the wound immediately
questions.solution:
The following measures should be taken immediately to stop the contraction of rabies:

  • Cleansing- The most important step in the prevention of rabies is washing the affected area with plain soap and water under a running tap for 15 minutes. This is a standard procedure that minimizes the contraction of rabies.
  • Chemical treatment- Irrigation of the wound should then be done with virucidal agents like alcohol, tincture, 0.01% solution of aqueous iodine, or povidone-iodine. Even irrigating the wound with cetrimide + chlorhexidine solution can be done. This process eliminates the residual virus in the wound
  • Suturing - Bite wounds are not sutured generally. If suturing is necessary, it is done after 24-48 hours under the cover of local infiltration of the rabies immunoglobulin which is generally done in category Ill wounds.
  • Other measures - Local antibiotics and tetanus toxoid should be given.

The correct measures taken are 1, 2, 3, and 4 only.

Reference: park textbook of preventive and social medicine 23rdedition Page no 276, 277, 278.

choices.text: Faith healers may be trained to diagnose and treat malaria cases
Social marketing to increase usage of mosquito repellent ointments
Provision of diagnosis and treatment facilities to labourers

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the key intervention of the Tribal Malaria Action Plan (TMAP)?
questions.solution:
• Social marketing to increase the usage of mosquito repellent ointments is not a part of the key intervention of the Tribal Malaria Action Plan (TMAP).
  • Social marketing is done to increase the usage of bed nets.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 450, 451

questions.text: A 23-year-old man came to you for nutritional advice. He is an alcoholic. Which of the following measures would not prevent the development of Wernicke's encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
• In the given clinical scenario, vitamin C supplementation would not prevent the development of Wernicke's encephalopathy.
  • In an alcoholic person, thiamine deficiency can cause Wernicke's encephalopathy. Hence, the measures to prevent thiamine deficiency are:
  • Cessation of alcohol
  • Including gingelly seeds (sesame seeds) in the diet because they have the highest content of thiamine
  • Consuming parboiled rice instead of milled or highly polished rice.
  • Thiamine is lost from rice during the process of milling.
  • Direct supplementation with thiamine.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 675, 676, 702

choices.text: It is a notifiable disease under the ESI Act, 1948
It is a notifiable disease under Coal Mines Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1947
It is a notifiable disease under the Factories Act, 1948
It is a notifiable disease under Maternity Benefit Act, 2017

questions.text:
The audiogram of a laborer working at a mining factory shows the following picture. Which of the following is true?
ESI - Employees State Insurance
questions.solution:
• In the given clinical scenario, the audiogram shows a dip at 4000Hz which is characteristic of noise-induced hearing loss.
  • It is a notifiable disease under the Factories Act, 1948.
  • The Factories Act, 1948 gives a schedule of notifiable diseases. There are 29 diseases notifiable to the government under this act. The 1976 amendment includes Byssinosis, Asbestosis, occupational dermatitis, and noise-induced hearing loss among the list of notifiable diseases.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 876

questions.text: There is a 40% chance of a person developing cancer in a population. What is the probability that all 4 randomly selected people from the population would have cancer?
questions.solution:
• In this scenario, the probability of all 4 randomly selected people getting cancer would be 0.0256.
  • The probability of a person developing cancer in the population is given by p (developing cancer) = 40/100 =0.4
  • If 4 people are randomly selected in a population, the chance of the first person having cancer is independent of the second/third/fourth also having it and vice-versa. This satisfies the condition for the multiplication rule of probability. It states that the probability of two or more statistically independent events all occurring is equal to the product of their individual probabilities.
  • Hence in this scenario, the probability that all 4 randomly selected people from the population would have cancer = 4 x 0.4 x 0.4 x 0.4 = 0.0256
  • Note: The (p) of any one of the 4 randomly selected people from the population having cancer = the sum of their individual probabilities = 0.4 + 0.4 + 0.4 + 0.4 = 1.6

Reference: High-Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health - 4th Edition Page No 1, 2

questions.text:
The district mental health program has incorporated promotive and preventive activities for positive mental health which includes the following
1. School mental health services
2. Workplace stress management
3. Ensuring equal human rights to mentally ill
4. Monitoring the conditions in mental health hospitals
5. Decriminalization of suicide
questions.solution:
• Statement 1 and 2 are the promotive and preventive activities for positive mental health incorporated under the District Mental Health Programme.
  • The district mental health program has incorporated promotive and preventive activities for positive mental health which includes the following :
    • School mental health services
    • Workplace stress management, College counselling services
    • Suicide prevention services
  • The condition in mental hospitals is monitored by the National Human Rights Commission.
  • Ensuring equal human rights to the mentally ill was introduced under the Mental Healthcare Bill, 2013.
  • Suicide has been decriminalized under the Mental Health Care Act 2017.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 513

questions.text: The concept of barefoot doctors belongs to which system of medicine?
questions.solution:
• The concept of barefoot doctors and acupuncture belongs to modern Chinese medicine.
  • Chinese medicine claims to be the world's first organized body of medical knowledge, as it dates 2700 B.C.
  • They are also the pioneers of immunization and practised variolation to prevent smallpox.

questions.text: A married couple has a child with thalassemia major. What preventive method would you use so that this couple does not give birth to another thalassemia-positive baby?
questions.solution:
• In this scenario, the couple can be prevented from giving birth to another thalassemia-positive baby by using retrospective genetic counselling.
  • Retrospective genetic counselling is the most common approach of counselling done presently for hereditary disorders that have already occurred within the family.
  • It is recommended by the WHO to establish enough genetic counselling centers in regions where infectious diseases and nutritional disorders have been brought under good control.
  • These centers should also be set up in areas where genetic diseases like sickle cell anemia and thalassemia are endemic.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No 889

questions.text: What is culture contact?
questions.solution:
• Culture contact is also known as acculturation.
  • Acculturation is the process by which there is the diffusion of cultures between two culturally different groups of people.

questions.text:
The benefits received under the Menstrual Hygiene Scheme are
1. A pack of 6 sanitary pads is provided to adolescent girls
2. The brand of sanitary pads sold is Today
3. These napkins are sold to adolescent girls at Rs. 1 for a pack of 6 napkins
4. These napkins are sold by the Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA)
5. On the sale of each pack, the ASHA gets an incentive of Rs. 1 per pack
questions.solution:
The benefits received under the Menstrual Hygiene Scheme are the following:

  • A pack of 6 sanitary napkins is provided under the National Rural Health Mission - NRHM's brand 'Freedays'.
  • These napkins are sold to adolescent girls at Rs. 6 for a pack of 6 napkins by the Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA).
  • On the sale of each pack, the ASHA gets an incentive of Rs. 1 per pack besides a free pack of sanitary napkins per month.

questions.text: A 29-year-old IT professional is in the second trimester of pregnancy. How much protein would you advise her to consume on a daily basis?
questions.solution:
• The recommended dietary allowance of protein for a pregnant woman in the second trimester is 5 g/day.
  • The national institute of nutrition recommends an DA of 46 g of protein per day, regardless of the woman's type of occupation and activity.
  • During pregnancy, the DA of protein is increased in the second and third trimesters.
  • In the second trimester, the RDA of protein is increased by 9.5 g/day to a total of 55.5 g/day.
  • In the third trimester, the DA of protein is increased by 22 g/day to a total of 68g/day.

Reference:

Online Resource: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rlhkilXwGZy8OEhejXnLhDBsOkMf86cq/view

Journal: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK221361/box/bbb00001/?report=objectonly

questions.solution:

questions.solution:

  • The discard point is when the colors of the circle and square are the same.

choices.text: Birth rate lower than the death rate
Declining death rate and declining birth rate
High birth rate and high death rate
Declining death rate and birth rate remains unchanged

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the stage of the demographic cycle that India is currently in?
questions.solution:
• India is curently in the 'late expanding' stage which is the third stage in the demographic cycle where declining death rates and declining birth rates are seen.
  • The demographic cycle is comprised of five stages and is as described below:
    • Stage 1: High stationary population - There is a high birth rate and a high death rate that cancel each other and the population remains stationary.
    • Stage 2: Early expanding population - There is a decline in the death rate that begins but the birth rate stays constant. Ex: Many countries in South Asia, and Africa are in this phase.
    • Stage 3: Late expanding population - There is a further fall in the death rate, with the birth rate beginning to fall. The population is still increasing due to a net increase in births. India has entered this phase.
    • Stage 4: Low stationary population - There is a low birth and low death rate, and this can result in a stationary population. It can also result in zero population growth like in Austria (1980-85). Other examples: the UK, Denmark, Sweden, Belgium recorded a growth rate of 0.1 in 1980-85. It has occurred in most industrialised countries as a demographic transition shifting from high birth and high death rates to low birth and low death rates.
    • Stage 5: Contracting population - The birth rate is lower than the death rate, causing population decline. Ex: East European countries like Germany, Hungary
  • Another important concept of the demographic cycle is the demographic gap which is the difference between birth rate and death rate. The demographic gap is maximum in the early-expanding phase, characterised by a high birth rate and low death rate. As the demography of the country transitions to the late-expanding phase, both birth rate and death rate falls causing a decreasing demographic gap. Although the birth rate is falling in the late-expanding phase, it is still higher than the death rate, which causes the population to increase.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no 530

questions.text:
A patient presents with sudden-onset fever, chills, headache, and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is a history of rodent infestation at his farm. He is diagnosed with a disease transmitted by the vector in the image below.


Identify the type of zoonosis and the biological transmission of the disease.
questions.solution:
• The given image above is of a rat flea, which transmits plague bacilli.
  • This is an example of propagative biological transmission.
  • In propagative biological transmission, the disease agent only multiplies in the vector but there is no change in form.
  • Plague is an example of meta zoonoses.

questions.text: All the treated waste from these bins can be sent to undergo any of the following disposal options except-
questions.solution:
• The given bins are red bins, which collect recyclable contaminated waste. It should not be sent to landfill sites as it contains plastics.
  • Treatment and disposal of recyclable contaminated waste are autoclaving/microwaving/hydroclaving
  • It is followed by shredding/mutilation. Then it is sent to registered or authorized recyclers. It can also be sent for energy recovery/plastics to diesel or fuel oil/for road making.
  • Plastic wastes are not sent to landfill sites.

choices.text: Series of speeches on the topic and the chairman summarizing at the end
Series of meetings with emphasis on individual work in a group
4-8 qualified persons sit and discuss the topic in front of an audience

questions.text: An annual symposium on diabetes mellitus is being conducted by a medical college. The event would most likely comprise of:
questions.solution:
• In the given scenario, the symposium would consist of a series of speeches on the topic and the chairman summarizing at the end.
  • A symposium is a series of speeches on a selected subject by experts. Each expert presents an aspect of the subject briefly after which the audience is allowed to ask questions.
  • There is no discussion among symposium members. The chairman makes a comprehensive summary at the end of the session.

Other options:

  • Option B - A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within the group, with the use of external consultants or experts.
  • Option C - Role-playing is the dramatization of social situations for health education by those taking part in it. The group members enact the roles while the audience is actively concerned with the drama. Role-playing is useful in discussing problems of human relationships.
  • Option D - Panel discussions comprises 4-8 qualified persons who sit together and discuss a topic in front of an audience.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no. 928

questions.text: A screening test was carried out among 124 people and 20 had the disease. Twenty-two showed positive tests among which 15 had the disease. What is the sensitivity of the test?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the sensitivity of the test is 75%

Positive results:

  • Out of the 22 positive results, 15 had the disease
  • So, number of true positives = 15
  • The remaining 7 people are false positives as they got the positive result but have no disease

Negative results:

  • The population who got negative results = 124 - 22 = 102
  • Of them, 5 are false negatives, because as per the question 20 had the disease. However, 15 of them got a positive result, so the remaining 5 are false negatives.

So the rest 97 (102 - 5) are true negatives

  • Sensitivity = True Positive (TP) / True positives (TP) + False Negatives (FN) x 100 = 15 / 15+5 × 100= 75%

Reference: Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 24th Edition Page no 149

questions.text: What is the most widely used legal addictive substance in India?
questions.solution:
• According to the national mental health survey of India, tobacco is the most widely used legal addictive substance in India.
  • It is associated with several conditions like oral cancer, lung cancer, periodontal disease, and cardiovascular disease.
  • Alcohol is the second most substance abused in India.

questions.text: A patient who was admitted to the ICU due to a road traffic accident later developed pneumonia. What time duration is required to declare it to be a hospital-acquired infection?
questions.solution:
• The criteria for surveillance of nosocomial respiratory infections are:
  • It is acquired due to cross-infection of a patient by other patients, hospital staff. It is a determinant of the poor quality of service provided by the hospital. It is also called nosocomial infections.
  • A hospital-acquired infection is defined as an infection acquired during hospital care that is not present or incubating at admission.
  • In the given clinical scenario, any infection occurring more than 48 hours after admission is usually considered a hospital-acquired infection.
    1. Cough
    2. Purulent sputum
    3. New infiltrate on radiograph consistent with infection

If any 2 of the above given 3 clinical features are present, a diagnosis of hospital-acquired respiratory infection is made.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no 387, 388

questions.text: A city has a population of 8,00,000 people. 4000 of them were diagnosed with COVID-19, out of which 100 died. What is the case fatality rate of COVID-19 in this city?
questions.solution:
• The case fatality rate of COVID-19 in this city is (100 deaths/4000 cases)x100 = 2.5%
  • Case fatality rate = Total number of deaths due to a particular disease X 100 / Total number of cases due to the same disease

questions.text: You conduct a study to determine the association between computer use and visual impairment and get a correlation coefficient of +0.4. Which of the following scattergrams best represents your findings?
questions.solution:
• In the given clinical scenario having a correlation coefficient of +4 shows a positive weak correlation and the scattergram that best represents this finding is the graph number 2.
  • Correlation (denoted by r) is used to assess the strength and direction of the association between two variables (such as smoking and lung cancer).
  • The correlation coefficient is represented by a plus or minus sign, followed by a number (Example: -0.88). The correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to +1.

Reference: High-Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology, and Public Health (High-yield Series) page no 38

questions.text:
During a medical camp at a school, you record the visual acuity of a child to be 6/30 for distant vision. According to IC 11, which category of visual impairment does the child fall under?
D 11- International Classification of Disease 11
questions.solution:
• A child having a visual acuity of 6/30 for distant vision falls under moderate distant vision impairment according to IC 11 classification.
  • Classification of visual impairment according to the International Classification of Disease 11 (2018):
    • Distance vision impairment:
    • Mild - Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12
    • Moderate - Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18
    • Severe - Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60
    • Blindness - Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60
    • Near vision impairment:
    • Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or N8 at 40cm with existing correction.
  • Blindness: According to WHO, blindness is defined as visual acuity of less than 3/60, or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10°, in the better eye with the best possible correction.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page No:430

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with diarrhoea is feeding well and is thirsty. Skin pinch when done returns in 4 seconds. Which of the following is appropriate for the management of this child in the first 4 hours?
questions.solution:
• According to the IMNCI classification, the baby has 'some dehydration' and should be managed according to Plan B.
  • The treatment under Plan B for a 14-month-old baby (1-2 years old) is 600-800 ml of ORS at home to be given in the first four hours.

questions.text: An epidemiologist collects data regarding life expectancy, schooling, and the per capita income of a select population. Which among the following is most likely being calculated by the epidemiologist?
questions.solution:
• Hence the 3 dimension indices used to calculate the human development index are as follows:
  • Human Development Index (HDI) is defined as 'a composite index focusing on three basic dimensions of human development: To lead a long and healthy life, measured by life expectancy at birth;the ability to acquire knowledge, measured by mean years of schooling;and the ability to achieve a decent standard of living, measured by gross national income per capita'.
  • The index that is calculated using the given indicators such as literacy rate, mean years of schooling, and gross national income per capita is the Human Developmental Index (HDI).
    1. Life expectancy index
    2. Education index
    3. Gross national index

questions.text: A hypertensive patient died of respiratory distress due to pneumonia caused by COVID-19 (test positive). What should be recorded in the line I (c) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
• COVID-19 will be filled in line I (c) of the death certificate, as it is the condition that gave rise to the antecedent cause (pneumonia).
  • In this patient:
    • I(a)- Disease directly leading to death: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
    • I(b)- Antecedent cause: Pneumonia
    • I(c)- Condition which gave rise to antecedent cause: COVID-19

References: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no: 64

questions.text: A 32-year-old working woman is pregnant, she already has 2 surviving children. According to the Maternity Act 2017, what duration of paid leave would she receive?
questions.solution:
• According to Maternity Act 2017, a working mother who already has 2 surviving children will be given a paid leave for a maximum duration of 12 weeks of which not more than 6 weeks precedes the expected date of delivery.

Reference: Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 24th Edition Page no 852

questions.text: You are a newly posted factory medical officer and you observe that the factory doesn't have proper ventilation which is not good for its workers. After your suggestion, the factory officials deploy the use of centrifugal fans and exhaust fans for proper ventilation. This type of ventilation is called
questions.solution:
• The mechanical system of ventilation which employs both plenum ventilation (centrifugal fans) and exhaust ventilation (exhaust fans), is called balanced ventilation.

References: Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 24th Edition Page no: 776

Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no: 799

choices.text: It is a method to measure the contraceptive efficacy
Total accidental pregnancies do not include abortions
Four months are deducted from total months of exposure for abortion
The number 1200 indicates the number of months in 100 years

questions.text:
While working in a family planning center, you have been advising couples regarding contraceptive methods. The curious interns ask you to explain the pearl index mentioned in a learning poster in the clinic. Which of the following points related to this would be incorrect?
Pearl index = (Total accidental pregnancies X 1200)/Total months of exposure
questions.solution:
• The option stating 'Total accidental pregnancies do not include abortions' is the incorrect statement.
  • Total accidental pregnancies include every form of conception, like live births, stillbirths, or abortions, or the pregnancy that has not yet been terminated.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no 561

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester is diagnosed with uncomplicated malaria and blood smear performed was found to be positive for plasmodium falciparum. Which one of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Falciparum malaria during the second and third trimester of pregnancy should be treated with ACT (Artemisinin-based combination therapy).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no 290

choices.text: Has siphon tube in larval stage
Wings are spotted in adult mosquitoes
These mosquitoes are vectors for malaria
Their eggs are laid singly, not in clusters

questions.text:
The larval stage of a mosquito is given below.


Which of the following is false regarding this species of mosquitoes?
questions.solution:
• The image shown is of an Anopheles larva, which can be identified as it lies parallel to the undersurface of water. It doesn't have a siphon tube in its larval stage.
  • They lay the eggs singly and adult mosquitoes' wings are spotted, whereas the other species of mosquitoes like Culex and mansonia lay eggs in clusters (except aedes) and their wings in the adult form are unspotted.
  • The Anopheles mosquitoes are vectors or carriers for malaria

References: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition Page no: 830

questions.text: SPIKES protocol is for:
questions.solution:
• SPIKES protocol is for breaking bad news.

S - setting

P- perception

I - invitation or information

K- knowledge

E- empathy

S - summarizing or strategizing

Reference:

Online Resource: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20682509
